questions.text: A 40-year-old male was found shot dead in a parking lot. Forensic examination revealed that the cause of death was a shotgun injury. Considering the type of injury, what is the probable range of the shot?
questions.explanation:
Shooting Range

Range

Wound Description

Contact shot

Muzzle in direct contact

Circular entry wound with muzzle imprint, severe tissue damage, blackening, and burning of the wound edges. Cherry-red tissue due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Close-shot (Option A)

< 1 meter

Circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing, singeing of hair, and cherry-red tissue discolouration due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Short-range (Option B)

1-2 meters

Circular 4-5 cm wound (Rat hole) with irregular borders, no blackening, burning, or tattooing.

Intermediate shot (Option C)

2-4 meters

Large, irregular wound surrounded by multiple satellite wounds.

Distant shot (Option D)

> 4 meters

The entry wound fades, leaving multiple small pellet wounds.

questions.text: A 40-year-old laborer was involved in an explosion at a chemical plant caused by a faulty pressure valve. Rescued from a confined space, he arrived at the emergency department with respiratory distress and injuries shown in the image. What type of injury describes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of injury

Caused by

Features

Primary blast injury

(Option A)

Blast waves
  • Commonly internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture
  • Lungs: Alveolar, capillary, and membrane hemorrhage leading to blast lung (most common causes of death among survivors)
  • GIT: Vomiting, melena, hematemesis, perforation.

Secondary blast injury

(Option B)

Shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion)
  • Penetrating trauma
  • Marshall triad: Includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations.
  • Thoracic injuries

Tertiary blast injury

(Option C)

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds
  • Blunt or penetrating trauma.
  • Bone fractures and coup-countercoup injury.

Quaternary blast injury

(Option D)

Environmental contaminants, chemicals, radiations (nuclear bomb), virus and bacteria
  • Flash burns, crush injuries
  • Fall resulting from the explosion
  • Traumatic asphyxia and respiratory injuries
  • Psychiatric injury
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male diver is brought to the emergency department after an underwater explosion and complains of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and difficulty breathing. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the abdomen. Which organ is most commonly injured in this patient due to the underwater blast?

A 35-year-old male construction worker was involved in a workplace explosion. Positioned near the blast's epicenter, he was swiftly taken to the emergency department with multiple injuries, including punctate abrasions, contusions, and lacerations as depicted in the image. What type of blast injury is most likely in this case?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.

questions.text: In the forensic analysis of cranial fractures, Puppe's Rule is applied to determine the sequence of impacts. According to this rule, when two fracture lines intersect ,as shown below, what can be inferred about their relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: The line that ends at the intersection is the newer injury.

options.label: B
options.text: The second fracture line crosses the first line.

options.label: C
options.text: Both fracture lines are of equal age.

options.label: D
options.text: Crossing fracture indicates a higher velocity impact.

questions.correct_answer: A. The line that ends at the intersection is the newer injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was found dead in an abandoned warehouse due to a shotgun wound to the chest. Analysis indicated that the shotgun pellets caused an effect where multiple pellets, fired from a high range, impacted the same area, leading to significant damage and a larger wound channel. What effect is being described here?
questions.explanation:
Billiard ball effect

(Billiard Ball Ricochet Effect) (Option A)

Balling or welding

(Option B)

When shotgun pellets enter tissue, the first pellets slow down and are struck from behind by subsequent pellets, causing them to scatter through the tissue like a cluster of billiard balls hit by the cue ball.

In distant shots, the pellets can merge into a compact mass, causing the lead shots to stick together and create a larger entry wound while exhibiting some dispersion.
It occurs due to:

  • Faulty manufacture (too much powder, poor pressure of wads,paraffin into cartridge case)
  • Old ammunition

Very high dispersion (due to resistance)

Less dispersion

Low range (near shot resembles distant range)

High range (wound mimics intermediate shot)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was shot during a robbery while walking home at night. The weapon used was identified as a firearm, and forensic investigators recovered a bullet from the scene, as shown in the image below. Identify it.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Images

Dum-dum bullet

(Option D)

A jacketed bullet that leaves an area near the nose uncovered to expose the core.

Hollow point bullet

(Option A)

The modern Dum Dum bullet features a pit at the nose. Upon impact, pressure in the pit causes the lead ring to expand into a mushroom shape, resulting in increased soft tissue damage and a higher incapacitation index.

Soft point bullet

A jacketed bullet with an open tip that exposes some lead inside expands upon impact but more slowly than a hollow-point bullet.

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet)

Bullets eject one after another when the first bullet fails to exit the barrel and is pushed out by a subsequently fired bullet (faulty ammunition or a firearm that hasn't been used for years).

Duplex bullet

It contains two projectiles by design (used in military rifles) and enters a target at different points.

Frangible bullet

Designed to fragment or disintegrate upon impact, made of copper, powdered tungsten, lead, or iron. They do not ricochet.

Souvenir or sleeping

Bullet (Option B)

A bullet remains in the body for a long time without fresh bleeding, surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. It can result in lead poisoning.

  

Armour-piercing bullet

A jacketed bullet (penetrates armour) with an inner core of hard, high-density metal like tungsten, tungsten carbide, depleted uranium, or steel, featuring a truncated cone.

Incendiary bullet

(Option C)

A type of military bullet designed to ignite a fire in the target.

Tracer bullet

It leaves a visible mark or "trace" during flight, allowing the shooter to see where the shot impacts.

Nontoxic shot or Green bullet

It replaces the copper-jacketed lead core with a copper-jacketed tungsten, steel, bismuth, tin, or nylon core. It does not release toxic lead (lead-free) into the environment (green bullet).

Exploding bullet

A bullet designed to detonate or break apart uses an explosive or deflagrant, causing extensive damage to the victim. These bullets pose a risk to medical personnel, as they may explode during procedures if they fail to detonate in the body.

Boat tail bullet

The cartridge's rear end is tapered rather than squared off to stabilise the projectile in flight.

Poisoned bullets

Contains curare, ricin or aflatoxin.

  

Wadcutter

Specifically designed for shooting paper targets at close range and high velocities.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was participating in a target shooting session at a local outdoor range when he accidentally fired a bullet that deflected off a metal target and struck another participant, resulting in his death. Which of the following best describes the bullet?

A 45-year-old male was found dead after a suspected shooting incident involving a shotgun. During the investigation, experts examined the shotgun's characteristics to determine factors affecting its range. Which of the following does not enhance the range of shotguns?
questions.explanation:
Type

Range

Cylindrical base (unchoked)

25 yards

Improved cylindrical choke

30 yads

Modified cylindrical choke

35 yards

Full choke

40 yards

questions.text: A forensic investigation was launched after a 20-year-old boy was found dead with a bullet in his body, showing signs of burning, blackening, and tattooing. At what distance does a shotgun produce a flame effect?
questions.explanation:
Effects

Rifle

Shotgun

Flame

(burning)

7 cm (Option A)

15 cm (Option B)

Smoke or soot

(blackening)

30 cm (Option C)

45 cm (Option D)

Gunpowder

(tattooing)

60-90 cm

60-90 cm

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was shot outside a nightclub late at night. Witnesses reported hearing gunshots and saw a dark sedan fleeing the scene. Police found shell casings and a bloodstained area, collecting gunshot residue (GSR) samples from the victim's hands and clothing. Which of the following is the most specific gunshot residue test?
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Harrison and Gilroy test (Option A)

A qualitative calorimetric chemical test detects antimony, barium, and lead but is not specific to firearm discharge residues.

Atomic absorption Spectrometry (AAS) &

Flameless atomic absorption spectrophotometry (FAAS)

(Option B)
  • Uses high temperatures to vaporise metallic elements in primer residues for detection and quantification.
  • Measuring antimony, barium, and lead from the primer, along with copper from the cartridge case or bullet jacketing.

Neutron activation analysis

(Option C)
  • Identifies minute traces of elements in hair, nails, soil, glass, paint, gunshot residue (GSR), and drugs by detecting radioisotopes formed through irradiation in a nuclear reactor.
  • Antimony and copper residues from the primer can be found on the suspect's hand.

SEM-EDXA (Scanning electron microscopy energy dispersive X-ray analysis) (Option D)
  • It is the most advanced tool for detecting minute traces of gunshot residue (GSR) on a suspect's body, providing qualitative rather than quantitative analysis.
  • It is the most specific test.

Dermal Nitrate Test (Paraffin Test)

An obsolete and non-specific method for detecting gunshot residue (GSR) by identifying nitrates and nitrites on a suspect's hand

Test

Description

Modified Greiss test

It uses chemicals such as alpha-naphthol to visually reveal the GSR pattern and particle density (specific for nitrites).

Sodium rhodizonate reaction

Detects lead from primer residue or bullet wipe.

Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX)

It detects barium, antimony, lead, and copper around the entry wound in clothing and can be used to determine the range of fire.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female is found deceased in an urban park with a single gunshot wound to the left side of her chest. Forensic analysis suggests the shot was fired from a distance, with no evidence of close-range effects like soot, muzzle imprint, or stippling. Which of the following is a feature of the entry wound?

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of cherry red wound track

questions.correct_answer: D. Presence of cherry red wound track
questions.explanation:
Entry wound

Exit wound

Size and shape

(compared with a bullet)

Small, clean, circular wound

Large (except in contact shot), Irregular, stellate-shaped wound. (Option B)

Margins

Inverted

Everted (Option C)

Abrasion & Grease collar

Present

Absent (except in shored exit)

 

*Shored exit: When the skin at an exit wound is supported by firm objects, tight clothing, or a body leaning against a hard surface, the wound appears as a circular defect with an abrasion margin similar to an entry wound. The pattern of the overlying material may also be imprinted on the wound's edges.

Burning, blackening & tattooing

Present

Absent

Skull


 

Inner table: Beveled

Outer table: Clean cut

Inner table: Clean cut

Outer table: Beveled

Cherry-red wound track

Present (might be) (Option D)

Absent

Bleeding

Less

More

Fat and soft tissue expulsion

Absent

Present (Option A)

Lead ring

May be present

Absent

Cloth fibres

Turned in

Turned out

Spectrograph

More metal found

Less metal found

questions.text: In a forensic investigation of a 45-year-old male found dead from a gunshot wound, the scene indicates forced entry, with the front door ajar and a bullet and shell casing collected. Which of the following are not considered primary markings on the bullet?

options.label: A
options.text: Diameter and width of lands and grooves

questions.correct_answer: D. Surface irregularities from barrel imperfections
questions.explanation:
Primary Markings (Class characteristics)

Secondary Markings (Individual or accidental characteristics)
  • Determined by manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions are most useful for identifying the make and model of the firearm involved.
  • It consists of:
    • Number, diameter and width of lands and grooves (Option A, B)
    • Depth of grooves
    • Direction and degree of rifling twist (Option C)

Surface irregularities (Option D) on the bullet result from imperfections in the barrel and the adhesion of bullet particles to the bore during firing (Metallic Fouling).

It may be identical for bullets fired by two different weapons.

These are different for bullets fired by two different weapons, reflecting each firearm's distinct barrel characteristics.

It's more pronounced for jacketed bullets.

It is more pronounced when the grooves deeply mark the lead bullet.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found lying in the driveway with multiple gunshot wounds and is pronounced dead at the scene. Which component is responsible for the effects depicted in the wound image?
questions.explanation:
Effects

Components causing the effect

Blackening (soot or smoke soiling or smudging)

Powder soot (carbon) deposition (Option A)

Tattooing or peppering or stippling

Unburnt or partially burnt gunpowder granules (Option C)

Burning or singeing

Flame (Option B)

  • Barium nitrate (Option C)
  • Lead peroxide
  • Antimony sulphide (Option B)
  • Styphnate
  • Tetrazine (Option A)

Which of the following statements are true regarding the type of gunpowder commonly used in fireworks? Produces less smoke compared to newer gun powders Produces more heat and flame while burning 1gm of this powder produces 3000cc of gas It contains only Sulphur and Charcoal It is used in the composition of Semi smokeless gunpowder

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of the structure labeled “X” in the image?

options.label: C
options.text: Allows gas to escape from the breech end

questions.correct_answer: C. Allows gas to escape from the breech end

questions.text: During a forensic examination of a shooting incident, a medical examiner discovers both shotgun pellets and rifle bullets at the crime scene. The examiner notes the differences in their design and function. Which statement about these ammunition types is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Shotgun cartridges contain multiple projectiles that spread upon firing.

options.label: B
options.text: Wads are used in all types of cartridges

options.label: C
options.text: Rifle bullets are generally elongated with a pointed tip

options.label: D
options.text: Rifle bullets and shotgun pellets are made of lead

questions.correct_answer: B. Wads are used in all types of cartridges
questions.explanation:
Cartridge of Rifle

Cartridge of Shotgun
  • Contains a primer on the base and a cartridge case filled with gunpowder.
  • Features a single projectile (bullet).
  • Does not include a wad (Option B)
  • Contains lead shots (Option D)/Pellets (Multiple Projectiles) (Option A)
  • Wads: Used only in smoothbore weapons (Shotguns).
  • Advantages of Wads:
    • Facilitates optimal pressure.
    • Prevents gas escape from the bore.
    • Aids in lubrication.
    • Stops gas from escaping at the breech end.
    • Maintains separation between the propellant and projectiles.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation, experts discussed the benefits of rifled firearms and how rifling impacts evidence collection. All the following are advantages of rifling except?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases accuracy by stabilizing the bullet

options.label: B
options.text: Improves range by imparting spin to the projectile

options.label: D
options.text: Reduces wobbling of the bullet in flight

questions.explanation:
Choking

Rifling ( Rifled Firearms)
  • Definition: Choking refers to the constriction at the muzzle end of a shotgun barrel.
  • Types:
    • Cylinder Bore: The barrel has a uniform diameter throughout.
    • Choke Bore: The muzzle is slightly constricted.
  • Degrees of Choke: Full, modified, improved cylinder, and cylinder.
  • Advantages of Choking:
    • Reduces shot spread.
    • Increases explosive force.
    • Enhances velocity and range.
  • Dispersion: A fully choked barrel produces shot dispersion that is half that of a cylinder bore.
  • As the bullet travels through the bore, it engages with the rifling, imparting a spin that enhances accuracy and stability. Each weapon leaves a unique marking on the bullet, aiding forensic identification.
  • Advantages of Rifling:
    • Gyroscopic Stability
    • Increased Accuracy (Option A):
    • Increased Range (stability and spin) (Option B)
    • Reduced Wobbling (Option D) (tumbling end-over-end during flight)
    • Greater Penetration Power

questions.text: During a forensic analysis of a crime scene, investigators examined firearms and noted the distinctions between rifled and smooth-bore firearms. Which of the following is true regarding rifled and smooth-bore firearms

options.label: A
options.text: Rifled firearms usually have multiple projectiles

options.label: B
options.text: Smooth-bore firearms include handguns and revolvers

options.label: C
options.text: Shotguns typically have a smooth barrel

options.label: D
options.text: Smooth-bore firearms typically don’t have chokes

questions.correct_answer: C. Shotguns typically have a smooth barrel
questions.explanation:
Feature

Rifled Firearms

Smooth Bore Firearms

Barrel Interior

Contains spiral grooves (Rifling)

Uniformly smooth barrel without grooves

Measurement

Caliber: Diameter between opposite lands, measured before rifling grooves are cut.

Bore: Defined by the number of lead balls of a specific size (diameter) that can be made from one pound of lead (454 grams).

Bullet Type

Typically fires a single projectile (bullet) (Option A)

Fires multiple pellets (shot) or a single slug

Accuracy

Higher due to rifling

Lower accuracy, designed for spread over a wide area.

Functionality

Imparts spin to the bullet for greater stability and precision

Fires multiple projectiles simultaneously for short-range effectiveness

Choke

Usually not applicable

May have chokes to control the spread of the shot (Option D)

Examples

Rifles, Pistols, Revolvers (Option B)

Shotguns

questions.text: At a forensic lab, a team was examining evidence from a recent shooting. One forensic analyst pointed out that identifying the caliber of the gun can help in linking it to a specific weapon. What does the term "caliber" refer to in forensic ballistics?

options.label: C
options.text: Muzzle design influencing the dispersion of shot

options.label: D
options.text: Measurement of the diameter of the shotgun barrel

questions.correct_answer: A. Distance between two opposite lands
